loan.name: Christine Luyombya 's Group

texts.en: Christine is the leader of a five-member group. She is 52 years old, married, and has six children between the ages of 18 and 34. The youngest one is still in school, the rest are working. She owns a six-room house where she lives with six people and takes care of three orphans. They have electricity and piped water at home. The family gets four meals a day. She resides and works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala. She runs Christine Retail shop, which sells general merchandise. Christine has about 15 customers a day. Her major monthly expenses include rent for the business premises at 50000 per month and the water and electricity bills. Christine has been with MCDT for seven years and is requesting her seventh loan. Her first business was poultry faming, but she has changed to selling general merchandise. She has worked with the same group mates for the past seven years. Christine will use this loan to invest in her business. She wants to expand her business and be able to do shopping in Dubai.

loan.use: TO boost her business

loan.name: Gulnoza

texts.en: Gulnoza K. is 27 years old. She is the loving mother of 2 adorable kids. Gulnoza and her husband are living together with her husband's parents. In order to help her husband to support their large family, Gulnoza started her own business. For the last 5 years, Gulnoza has been raising cattle and then selling them at the market. At the same time, she provides her family with milk products. With the help of loan, she plans to increase her livestock and also to construct a comfortable winter cowshed.

loan.use: To increase livestock and construct a winter cowshed

loan.name: Juliet Kusemerwa's Group

texts.en:
Juliet is the leader of 4 members of a group. She is a 35-year-old married woman with 4 children, aged between 20 and 10. They are all in school. She resides in and owns a 4-room house, where she is staying with 3 people and doesn't take care of any other additional family members. They neither have electricity nor water at home.

The family gets 3 meals a day. She resides and works in a semi-urban area that is on the outskirts of Kampala. Juliet runs a kiosk selling soft drinks and other food in Namungoona, near Kampala city. Juliet uses public transport to go to and from her shopping. Juliet receives over 30 customers a day and works 7 days a week. Juliet sells to all categories of people, and her major monthly expenses include rent for the business premises and medication. Juliet has been with MCDT for 4 years and is servicing her tenth loan, working all this long with the same group mates.

She wants to use this loan to buy another fridge.

loan.use: To buy another fridge

loan.name: Sanja

texts.en: Sanja was born in 1974 and she lives in Doboj, a small city in northeast Bosnia. She has one child and a husband who works outside of Bosnia, building homes. Sanja is interested in fashion. She designs, tailors, and sells her own clothing. Her customer base is currently her relatives and friends, but she has started to fill orders from third parties. To help her business grow, Sanja requests a 1,200KM ($850 USD) loan from Women for Women International with which she will buy materials for tailoring new clothing from her new designs.

loan.use: To buy material

loan.name: Prossy Kabejja's Group

texts.en:
Prossy is the leader of 4 members of a group. She is a 50-year-old divorced woman with 2 children, aged 17 and 15. Both her children go to school. She resides in and rents a one-room house, where she is staying with 3 people. Prossy takes care of her old mother. They do have electricity but no piped water at home. The family gets 3 meals a day.

She resides and works in a semi-urban area that is on the outskirts of Kampala. Prossy sells secondhand clothes in Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Kampala. On average she can sell to 10 people a day. Prossy has been in this business for 5 years and works 7 days a week. Formerly Prossy was operating a restaurant at her residence. Her major challenges are the rainy season, seasonality, and business taxes, and feeding the family is at times difficult.

Prossy has been with MCDT for 4 years and is servicing her seventh loan. She is aspiring to see her business expand so that she can start selling wholesale.

loan.use: To invest in her business

loan.name: Mersija

texts.en:
Mersija was born in 1988 and she lives in Odak, a small city in the north of Bosnia. She has two jobs with which she supports her family: she repairs shoes and she sells cosmetics out of a catalog. With these jobs, she makes just enough income to meet her family's daily needs, earning about 400KM/month, roughly equivalent to $290 USD.
Mersija requests a 700KM ($500 USD) loan from Women for Women International to support both businesses. She will buy new tools with which she can fix shoes, and cosmetic products that she can sell at a profit.

loan.use: To buy cosmeticts and new tools with which to repair shoes

loan.name: Mohammad

texts.en:
Mohammad is a married and an educated man who has a vehicle paint shop. He got his first-cycle loan and completed his stock and still he is furthering his business. He is a good client. When a Kiva fellow came to Afghanistan and saw this business, he was really very happy. Mohammad wants to continue his partnership with both Kiva and Ariana.

He has requested his second-cycle loan to enlarge his shop and complete his materials and also hire one or two more workers for his shop because now he is improving, he can be a good vehicle painter among other shopkeepers in the town.

He is happy with this loan process. When he found AFSG and started his partnership and until now: during this time he has never been faced with any difficulty, therefore he would like to thank lenders around the world who help those who really want to expand their business.

loan.use: To enlarge his shop and complete his materials

loan.name: Branka

texts.en: Branka was born in 1982 and she lives in Doboj, Bosnia. She currently takes care of her two young children, and runs a small daycare center out of her home. Branka requests a 1,500KM loan from Women for Women International, which she will use to buy supplies to accommodate more children for her daycare center. These supplies include beds, walkers for toddlers, books, and toys. She hopes to eventually take care of up to 10 children, ranging in age from 5 months to 7 years. She needs this daycare business to supplement the income of her husband. He has a steady job, working outside of Bosnia as a driver, but he does not earn enough income to support a family of four.

loan.use: To purchase beds, walkers for toddlers, books and toys for her daycare center.

loan.name: Jamshed

texts.en: Jamshed has owned a transportation business for the past 2 years. He transports people around his town. As he is the only bread-winner in his family, his car service business is the only source of family income. When he bought his car it was new, but as his auto is always on the move it is in need of some repairs. This loan will help to make a fast and quality repair of his car.

loan.use: Repairing his car

loan.name: Ismeta

texts.en: Ismeta was born in 1958 and she lives in Odak, a small city in the north of Bosnia. Her husband works as a tree seller and she works in the home, growing vegetables and raising poultry to help support the family. Ismeta requests a 800KM ($575 USD) loan from Women for Women International which she will use to purchase baby chicks and supplies. She plans to raise the chicks and sell their meat when they become adults. This will be her second microfinance loan; her first loan was also used to buy baby chicks, and she paid it back successfully.

loan.use: To buy baby chicks and supplies

loan.name: Amina's Group

texts.en:
Amina has been keeping chickens in Zanzibar since 2006. She is 23 years old, married, and has no children. She is now hoping to take out her first loan so that she may expand her livestock business and increase her profit.

Amina will share this loan with her fellow group members, Asha, Stara and Asha.

loan.use: To buy more chickens for her livestock business.

loan.name: Hakim

texts.en: Hakim works transporting goods and people in his town. Hakim used to work selling food, but the business did not provide enough income to support his family. He has a wife and two children. His wife takes care of the children and home. Hakim is the only one who earns money for the family. He owns his car, but it is now in need of some thorough repairs. This loan will help to make a quality and fast repair.

loan.use: Repairing his car

loan.name: Azra

texts.en:
Azra was born in 1986 and she lives in Brijesnica Mala, a small town in Bosnia. Her parents are low-income farmers and former refugees, but they managed to put her through college. She just graduated with a degree in law, but she is struggling to find work and is currently unemployed. While she hopes to some day practice law, in the meantime she is living with her parents, brother and grandmother and helping them in the field to raise cows and chickens.

Azra has started using her computer skills to prepare and format documents for local schools and businesses. These documents include contracts, inventory lists and diplomas. She requests a loan of 600KM from Women for Women International, which she will use to purchase a new printer and scanner, allowing her to offer more products for her customers. She hopes to use the income from this business to pay back her parents on the farm, who paid for her to attend college.

loan.use: To purchase a printer and scanner.

loan.name: Mirzoiskandar

texts.en: Mirzoiskandar has owned a goods transportation service business for 2 years. He is the sole supporter of his family. His truck is beginning to wear and he would like to borrow money in order to repair it. With a truck that runs more efficiently he can offer a better quality service to his customers.

loan.use: To repair his truck

loan.name: Mrs. Vun Morn Group

texts.en:
Mrs.Vun M. is a group leader of five, all of whom live in Tbeng Khpuos Village in the Kampong Chhnang Province. She is a farmer and owns two hectares of rice fields. On her plantation, she now faces a small problem because her soil is not fertile. To solve this problem, she decided to ask for a loan to purchase more fertilizers to support the field to make her crop more productive. Her husband, Mr. Kong Vong, helps her on the plantation. Mrs.Vun M. is 28-years-old and the mother of a child who is too young to work or study.

This is a group loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Four members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. Group members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to do so. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loan.use: To purchase more fertilizers to support the soil and make the rice fields more productive.

loan.name: Hanumica

texts.en:
Hanumica was born in 1946 and lives in Doboj, Bosnia. For most of her life, she worked as a housewife. Now she is a widow and lives alone, surviving largely on payments from her late husband`s pension plan. These payments provide her with barely enough income to meet her basic needs, so she has started selling skin-care products on the side. The skin-care products are natural and environmentally friendly, and are popular in Bosnia and Croatia.

Hanumica requests a loan of 1,000 KM ($700 USD) through Women for Women International. She will use the loan to purchase make-up products, expanding her product offering beyond skin care. She expects that this will help her to attract new customers. This will be her sixth microfinance loan, all of which she paid back successfully in the past.

Hanumica says that the income she receives from selling skin-care products is not significant, but even the small amount of income helps. And like most women, she likes the free products she gets from the job.

loan.use: To purchase cosmetic products

loan.name: Toni

texts.en: Toni lives in Al Ferzol, an area of the magnificent Bekaa valley of Lebanon. A single young man of 28, he has been teaching at a local school since 2001. Because transportation means are scarce in his region, Toni started his own business by buying a small bus and offering transportation services to the school's children. Since then, Toni has been driving students to and from school every morning and evening. As the harsh winter season is approaching, Toni wishes to borrow $1200 to perform maintenance on his van and change the tires of the vehicle before the valley becomes covered in snow.

loan.use: to perform maintenace on bus

loan.name: Mrs. Yoem Sopheap Group

texts.en:
The group leader of five is Mrs. Yoem S. and all of the members live in Rolaing Village in the Kampong Chhnang Province. Mrs. Yoem S., 46, and her husband are farmers who own two hectares of land to cultivate rice. They currently face a small problem because their soil is infertile. She has decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizer to support the soil and improve her crop. The couple has one child who is too young to work or study.

This is a group loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Four members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. Group members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to do so. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

Mr. Khun K.'s wife is present in the picture.

loan.use: To buy fertilizer to support the soil and improve the rice crop.

loan.name: Ibrahim

texts.en: Ibrahim lives in a small village near the Southern Lebanese city of Tyre. He is a 55-year-old man, married, with 4 children. Ibrahim owns a mini market and wants to expand his product offerings to better serve his clients. Ibrahim has asked for a loan of $500 to do so. This will be Ibrahim's first loan, but he is confident that this will be the beginning of a strong relationship, and is grateful for this opportunity.

loan.use: to purchase new products for his mini-market

loan.name: Anonymous Group
loan.use: To buy fertilizer

loan.name: Chuon

texts.en:
Chuon S., age 45, is married and lives with four of her five children in Prey Veng Province, Cambodia. Working as a cow dealer with her husband, Chuon S. typically makes $10 each day. Her family is also supported by three of their children who work in the garment factory and in a casino.
The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year and inflation has been out of control. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Chuon S. included. In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of $350 to buy a cow, a purchase that she believes can increase her daily income.
Mrs. S.'s husband appears in the photograph.

loan.use: To purchase a cow.

loan.name: Omega

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 26-year-old Omega P. N. from Kyela. Married with a one-year-old child, she is responsible for supporting one dependent whose parents died of HIV. Omega has been running a tailoring business making dresses and trousers and selling clothes since 2005. Assisted by her husband, she works 16 hours per day, 6 days per week and currently earns about $120 each month from her business.

Omega is requesting a loan of $450 in order to buy material in bulk to make clothes. In the future, she plans to enlarge her business. Omega thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loan.use: To buy clothing material in bulk.

loan.name: Cheung

texts.en:
Cheung M., age 33, is married and lives in Prey Veng, about 80 miles from Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia.
Mrs. M. typically makes $8 each day by selling vegetables in the village. Her husband, Rous Phirun, age 34, is a security guard who makes $2 each day. This couple has four children, one of whom is employed as garment factory worker with a salary $60 per month.
Cheung would like to take a loan of $800 to purchase a motorbike for her husband for commute to work. The motorbike will cost around $600. With the remaining $200, she will repair the leaky roof of her house.

loan.use: To purchase a motorbike for her husband to commute to work.

loan.name: Mohammed

texts.en: Mohammed is a 24-year-old man who lives near the Southern Lebanese city of Tyre. Mohammed owns a car washing garage and would like to take out a loan of $1000 to perform maintenance on the air compressor and winch which he uses to clean vehicles. This is the first time that Mohammed has asked for a loan.

loan.use: to perform repairs on car-washing machinery

loan.name: Touch

texts.en:
Touch S., age 44, is married and lives with two of her children in Prey Veng, Cambodia. Since 2007, she has been selling Khmer cake to earn a living and is able to make $3 each day. Her husband, Huy Rin, 45, is a construction foreman. On average, he makes $7 per day. This couple also gets support from their children who work, one in garment factory and another as a construction worker building houses.
Touch S. would like to borrow $1100 to purchase a motorbike for her husband and her children to commute to work. This will reduce the daily expenses that her family members spend on motor-taxis.
Mrs. Touch's husband appears in the photograph.

loan.use: To purchase a motorbike to commute to work

loan.name: Scolastica B.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 26-year-old Scolastica B. M. from Kyela, divorced with one child aged 12. Since 2005, Scolastica has been operating a shop selling items such as rice, maize flour, cooking oil, and salt. Assisted by her sister, she works at the business 12 hours per day, 6 days per week and earns about $110 each month.

Scolastica is requesting a loan of $800 to purchase more food items in bulk and as well as open a cosmetics shop alongside her shop. She thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loan.use: To purchase more food items in bulk and open a cosmetics shop.

loan.name: Ret's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Ret L., 29, is a vegetable seller. She grows vegetables and sells them at the market, earning approximately US$2.16 per day. She is married with four children, all of whom are students. Unfortunately, insects often ravage her vegetable crop. To address this problem, Ret is seeking a loan in the amount of US$250 to buy insecticide in order to protect her vegetable crop and to buy more seeds in order to grow additional vegetables. In turn, she expects that the loan will enable her to increase her family's income. Ret is the leader of a small group of three members who live in Paksneng Commune, Siem Reap Province. For greater clarity, the group members are described briefly below.

1. Mrs. Leab M., 51 years old and a widow, grows and sells vegetables. Leab requests a loan in the amount of US$200 to purchase insecticide to use on her vegetable crop.

2. Mr. Sary V., 28, makes and sells charcoal from his house. Sary requests a loan in the amount of US$200 to grow rice by plowing his farmland.

3. Mrs. Sophal S., 38 years old and a widow, is a vegetable grower. Sophal requests a loan in the amount of US$250 to purchase insecticide to use on her vegetable crop.

loan.use: To purchase insecticide to protect crops and to purchase seeds to grow additional vegetables

loan.name: Chheng

texts.en:
Chheng A., age 35, is married and lives with her three children in Prey Veng, Cambodia. Since 2006, she has sold fish to earn a living, and she is able to make $6 per day. Her husband has business running a motor-taxi, making $4 per day.
She said that selling fish is no longer as lucrative a business as it had been before, because of the illegal fishing and high rate of inflation. She said that sometimes it is hard to purchase fish from a fisherman and, more importantly, the fish price has increased by up to 60 percent. Due to the huge price increases, people have turned to meat, instead of fish.
She also described the difficulties of her husband's business, such as the high price of gas and the number of competitors. The high price of gas has put many motor-taxi drivers off of the road.
Mrs. Chheng A. would like to borrow $300, which she will use, along with her savings, to purchase a motorbike for her husband, so he can operate his motor-taxi business.
Mrs. A.'s husband appears in the photograph.

loan.use: To purchase a motorbike for her husband to operate a motor-taxi.

loan.name: Mostina A.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 40-year-old Mostina A. M. from Kyela, married with three children between the ages of 3 and 14. Mostina has been running a cereal crop shop since 2006, selling maize, rice, millet, beans, etc. Assisted by her husband, she works 12 hours per day, 6 days per week, earning about $175 each month from her business.

Mostina is requesting a loan of $400 in order to buy more cereal crops for reselling. In the future, she plans to own her own store so that she can fetch a higher price for her commodities. She thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loan.use: To buy more cereal crops for reselling.

loan.name: Maria R.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 45-year-old Maria R. B. from Kyela. She is married with four children between the ages of 17 and 34, and is also responsible for supporting two dependents whose family perished in a bus accident. Mariam has been running a mama lishe shop (caf) since 2005. Assisted by two employees and her husband, she works 12 hours per day, 6 days per week, earning about $122 each month from her business.

Maria is requesting a loan of $400 in order to buy a palm oil pressing machine so that she can produce palm oil for reselling. She thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loan.use: To buy a palm oil pressing machine.

loan.name: Sun

texts.en:
Sun S., age 62, is married and lives with three of her ten children in Prey Veng, Cambodia. She works with her husband as a farmer and makes less than one dollar each day. She said her farming just barely supports the family members.
This couple also is supported by five of their children who work in a garment factory. Farming uses a lot of labor and they need to have enough water or the yield will decrease and they might suffer crop damage. This couple grows rice twice a year, first in the rainy season, which is about 6-7 months long and second, in the dry season, which is about 3-4 months long.
To alleviate their daily expense and earn more profit, Sun S. is asking for a loan of $1200 to purchase a motorbike so that one of her sons can run a motor-taxi business.

loan.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loan.name: Hussein

texts.en: Hussein is a 39-year-old man. He lives with his wife and 5 children in a village near the ancient town of Baalback, in the Bekaa Valley. His eldest son is pictured here. Hussein has a farm and sells milk and other products produced by his livestock. Hussein has requested a loan of $1000 to purchase feed for his animals and diesel fuel for heating his home during the winter months. Temperatures in the valley during this time can get very cold and snow is frequent, so preparations for the cold winter are extremely important. This is the first time that Hussein has asked for a loan and he is grateful for the opportunity provided to him by Kiva lenders.

loan.use: to purchase feed for his livestock and fuel for home heating

loan.name: Tukusuma M.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 61-year-old Tukusuma M. M. from Kyela. Married with four children between the ages of 30 and 40, she is also responsible for supporting two dependents because they are orphans. Tunkunsuma has been running a shop since 2002 selling local beer, soft drinks, etc. Assisted by her children and husband, she works at the business 16 hours per day, 7 days per week, earning a monthly income of about $160.

She is requesting a loan of $800 to buy hard and soft drinks in bulk. In the future, she plans to have her own bar. Tukunsuma thanks you for your support! SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loan.use: To buy hard and sofrt drinks in bulk for her business.

loan.name: Bol

texts.en: Bol R., 57, is married and lives with two of her four children in the Prey Veng, Cambodia. She is a true entrepreneur who has a business selling porridge in the village. She has been doing that business since 2001 and is able to make US$3 per day, while her husband is a construction foreman and makes US$3 as well. Bol R. is asking for a loan from Kiva via CREDIT, a local partner, to purchase land for resale whenever the land price is high.

loan.use: To purchase land for resale.

loan.name: Mehriniso

texts.en: Mehriniso E. is 38 years old and she is the loving mother of 4 children. Mehriniso and her husband are living together with her husband's parents. In order to help her husband to support their large family, Mehriniso started her own business. For the last 2 years, Mehriniso has raised cattle and then sold them at the market. With the help of the loan, Mehriniso plans to increase her livestock and to generate additional profit.

loan.use: For business expansion

loan.name: Halima's Group

texts.en:
Halima has been selling udi in Zanzibar for one year. Udi is an object that Muslims burn for religious purposes and that produces a fragrance, much like incense. Halima sells udi both retail and wholesale. Because Zanzibar is nearly 100 percent Muslim, this is a successful business for Halima. She is hoping to take out this loan to expand her inventory and increase her profit. She is currently able to earn approximately $85 each month.

Halima is 36 years old, married, and has three children aged 12, 14, and 17. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Nadharia, Mayasa, Mwatumu, and Asha.

loan.use: To buy udi

loan.name: Christina A.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 46-year-old Christina A. M. from Kyela. Married with seven children between the ages of 16 and 22, she is also responsible for supporting three orphans. Christina, who has been selling cocoa since 2007, works at her business 12 hours per day, 6 days per week, assisted by her husband.

Currently earning about $70 each month from her business, she is requesting a loan of $400 in order to buy more fresh cocoa to resell. In the future, she plans to open a buying centre for her product. Christina thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loan.use: To buy fresh cocoa for resale.

loan.name: Mrs. Ky Hea Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Ky H. is the group leader of five who all live in Chrok Sangke Village in the Kampong Chhnang Province. Mrs. Ky H. owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. Since her plantation is currently infertile, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more fertilizers to improve her soil. Her husband, Mr. Vong Khon, is a laborer in a coal kiln and he also makes a small income to support his household.

Mrs. Ky H. is 46-years-old and the mother of nine children. Four children are employed in different business activities while two of them work on their parents plantation. The remaining three children are attending the local school.

loan.use: To buy more fertilizers to improve the soil for rice crops.

loan.name: Seng

texts.en:
Seng A., age 52, is a widow and lives with two of her four children in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. Since 2001, she has been making and selling many different kinds of baskets to eA. a living. She is able to make around $1.20 per day. She is aided by one child who works in garment factory.
Mrs. Seng would like to take a loan of $400 to make two investments. First, to purchase more bamboo to make baskets and second, to raise pigs.

loan.use: To purchase more bamboo and raise pigs.

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: Business expansion

loan.name: Lucy W.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 23-year-old Lucy W. S. from Tukuyu. She is married with one child, aged 3 years, and is also responsible for supporting one orphan whose parents died of HIV. Lucy has been running a home food item shop since 2006, selling commodities such as maize flour, beans, rice, and tomatoes. Assisted by her sister, she works 12 hours per day, 7 days per week, and currently earns about $60 per month from her business.

Lucy is requesting a loan of $400 in order to buy food items in bulk for her shop. In the future, she plans to have her own hotel. Lucy thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loan.use: To buy food items in bulk for her shop.

loan.name: Asha's Group

texts.en:
Asha has been selling charcoal and firewood in Zanzibar for two years. Because she serves her local community, she does not have strict opening and closing hours. Instead, her clients are free to seek her out at any time of the day or night to purchase firewood and charcoal from her. She currently earns approximately $45 in profit each month but she is hopeful that by expanding her inventory with this loan, her profit will increase.

Asha is 47 years old, divorced, and has four children. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Rahma, who also has a small business in Zanzibar.

loan.use: To buy more inventory of charcoal and firewood.

loan.name: Assim

texts.en:
Assim is a 44-year-old man who lives with his wife and 3 children in a small village in Lebanon's Bekaa Valley. Assim works as a calligrapher. Calligraphy in Arabic is a highly specialized craft, as the characters require a great degree of skill to design and perfect. Assim designs posters and signs for locA. businesses and individuals, and delivers his pieces himself.

He has recently requested a loan of 1000 US Dollars from A. Majmoua which will be used to purchase new materials for his shop, such as paints and stencils, as well as to perform maintenance on the van which he uses to deliver his work. This will be Assim's first loan with A. Majmoua.

loan.use: To purchase new materials for Assim's calligraphy business, as well as to perform repairs on the van he uses to deliver his products.

loan.name: Tep

texts.en: Mrs. Tep C. is a villager in Chan Teab Village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer who can make some money because she owns a small rice field. She is a 40-year-old widow and has a child who is 21-years-old and works as a laborer. Since her family is very poor, Mrs. Tep C. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow to for breeding and she hopes to increase her income after she sells the cow.

loan.use: To buy a cow for breeding and resale

loan.name: Chem

texts.en:
Chem C., 38, is a true entrepreneur and lives with four children in the Siem Reap, Cambodia. She works selling groceries and sugar cane juice from her home, making approximately US$ 5, while her husband works selling firewood and makes US$ 10 per day. One of her sons has a business selling sand and two others are students.

Chem C. would like to take out a loan of US$ 1000 to add grocery inventory; the remainder will be used to purchase a trailer for her husband to use to transport the wood.

loan.use: To add grocery inventory and purchase a trailer

loan.name: Mahina

texts.en: Mahina G. is 27 years old and is married with two small children. For the past 2 years Mahina has been selling clothes from her own trading place located in one of the local markets. Mahina is a very friendly and polite person and has been able to attract many customers. Mahina is requesting a loan to help expand her business and generate more income for family.

loan.use: Business expansion

loan.name: Meas

texts.en:
Mrs. Meas K. is a farmer in Boeng Kranh Village in the Takeo Province. Her husband, Mr. Un Sorn, uses his motorbike to carry a cart which is used to transport goods and passengers for a fee. Mrs. Meas K. is 50-years-old and the mother of four children. Two are employed in a garment factory while the remaining two are enrolled in the local school.

Although Mrs. Meas K.'s family members are employed in different businesses, they still cannot support their family. Mrs. Meas K. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. She hopes to increase her income after she sells that cow. Her husband is on the left of the photo.

loan.use: To buy a cow for breeding.

loan.name: Anna M.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 34-year-old Anna M. K. from Tukuyu. She is married with four children, between the ages of 4 and 15. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting one dependant whose parents cannot afford to send her to school. Anna has been running a banana shop since 2000. Her business is selling bananas in batches. She works at the business for 8 hours per day, 7 days per week, and currently earns about 120 USD from her business per month. She is requesting a loan of 325 USD in order to buy at wholesale price from farmers and to re-sell to business people from Dar es salaam. In the future, she plans to sell by going to Dar es salaam herself. Anna thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loan.use: To buy bananas at wholesale price from farmers to resell to business people from Dar es salaam.

loan.name: Suos

texts.en:
Mrs. Suos H. lives in Thorm Chey Village in the Takeo Province. She is a farmer who now faces a small problem because she does not have enough animals to cultivate her rice fields. In order to deal with this situation, she decided to ask for a loan to buy one more buffalo to add to the old one she currently uses as a draft animal.

Mrs. Suos H. is a 52-year-old widow with three children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory while the two are attending the local school.

loan.use: To buy one more buffalo to use as a draft animal in the rice fields.

loan.name: Run

texts.en:
Run P., age 28, is a mother of one child and lives with her husband in Siem Reap, Cambodia. She has a grinding mill and rents this machine to the people in the village. She earns a profit of $2 each day.
She also grows rice, but her farming just supports her family members. Her husband is a construction worker and makes $4 per day.
Run P. would like to take a loan of $1000 to purchase cow to help plow her farmland.

loan.use: To purchase cow to help plow her farmland.

loan.name: Salah

texts.en: Salah is a single young man. He is 28 years old and lives with his parents in a village near the city of Baalback in the Bekaa Valley. Salah is a professionA. blacksmith who works nearly every day of the year from 8:00 AM until 6:00 PM. Salah wishes to expand his business and has requested a loan of $1000 to do so.

loan.use: to expand his blacksmith business

loan.name: Kozima

texts.en: Kozima K. has been a widow for the past 15 years. Since she lost her husband, all family expenses fall on her shoulders. Kozima purchases dried apricots from small markets in her town, processes them at home and sells them at the central market every weekend. She has to wake up early in the morning to get the best apricots available at the best price. A loan would help her to expand her business and to reach her dream of providing a high education for her children.

loan.use: Expand and Grow her apricot business

loan.name: Rehema D.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 42-year-old Rehema D. M. from Tukuyu, married with three children between the ages of 8 and 18. Rehema, who has been running a hair salon since 2007, works at the business 10 hours per day, 7 days per week, earning about $100 monthly.

She is requesting a loan of $325 in order to buy salon items such as hair costmetics, nail polish, artificial hair, etc. In the future, she plans to open her own beauty boutique. Rehema thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loan.use: To buy salon items such as hair costmetics, nail polish, artificial hair, etc.

loan.name: Mwashamba's Group

texts.en:
Mwashamba has been selling dresses at her small shop in Zanzibar for 3 years. She also sells charcoal. She is 22 years old, single, and has no children. She is currently able to earn approximately $125 per month but is hoping that taking out her first loan through BRAC will allow her to increase her profit.

Mwashamba will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Safia, Megeni, Maembe, Hamida, and Salma.

loan.use: To buy more inventory for her dress shop

loan.name: Sarvar

texts.en: Sarvar K. is 46 years old and is married with two children. Mahina has been selling clothes for the past 13 years from her own trading place located in one of the local markets. She transports goods from the larger market of Istaravshan. Sarvar is requesting a loan to expand her business and generate more income.

loan.use: To expand her business

loan.name: Res

texts.en:
Res M., age 49, is a widowed fish seller who lives with two of her five children in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She typically makes $10 each day and is aided by her daughter, who works in a garment factory.
Res M. is asking for a loan of $400 to purchase a motorbike, a purchase that she sees as a good opportunity to increase her income.

loan.use: To buy a motorbike

loan.name: Almira

texts.en:
Almira was born in 1979 and she lives in a suburb of Doboj in Bosnia. She is married with two children. Her husband works as a bricklayer and tree-cutter, and Almira helps him with his tree-cutting business. This does not provide enough income to support her family, so Almira also works in the fields to grow sugarcane and pumpkins.

Almira requests a 600KM loan from Women for Women International to buy seeds and minerals for the autumn sowing. She hopes to have a harvest of sugarcane and pumpkins by the early spring.

loan.use: To buy seeds and minerals to grow sugarcane and pumpkins.

loan.name: Munavvara

texts.en: Munavvara K. is a 46 years old married woman with 4 children. Munavvara loves her children very much and she is trying to provide them with a better future. For the past 10 years, Munavvara has been selling clothes from her own trading place located in one of the local markets. She transports her goods from the larger markets of Dushanbe and Khujand. With the help of a loan she would like to expand business.

loan.use: To expand her business

loan.name: Saada's Group

texts.en:
Saada has been preparing and selling small food items in Zanzibar for 5 years. During this time, her business has grown to the extent that she now earns approximately $85 in profit each month. She's hoping that her first loan from BRAC Tanzania will enable her to expand beyond her current level of sales.

Saada is 42 years old, married, and has 5 children, ages 7, 15, and 22, along with 24-year-old twins. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Maria, Sabina, Fatma, Veronica, and Martina.

loan.use: To buy more ingredients for the food she cooks and sells

loan.name: Kurbonoi

texts.en: Kurbonoi M. is 48 years old and is the mother of two grown daughters and one grown son. Her husband moved to Russia to earn a better living. Kurbonoi started her own business to help support her family and for the last 12 years she has been selling clothes. She has her own trading area that is located in one of the local markets. Every week she transports goods from the larger Dushanbe and Khujand to her local market. Kurbonoi would like a loan to expand her business and promises to be on time with her loan payment

loan.use: To expand her business

loan.name: Zaimuddin

texts.en:
Zaimuddin K. lives in the Abdurahmon Jomi region. He has worked as a farmer for the last 8 years. Zaimuddin is married and has two children. He would like to take out this loan in order to purchase a large batch of seeds and fertilizer for the upcoming winter planting. Purchasing quality seeds will assure Zaimuddin a quality harvest in spring, and he will be able to sell his quality crops much faster at the market. Zaimuddin is planning to pay back the loan in the next 10 months.

Translated from Russian by Anya Lyuksyutova, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Purchase of seeds and fertilizer

loan.name: Lun

texts.en:
Lun L., 54, is a farmer, but she also sells dessert at her local market. In fact, she has been selling desserts since 2000, and she can earn approximately US$5 per day. Lun is married to Mr. Morn Ran, 68, who is also a farmer. More specifically, aside from her dessert-selling business, Lun takes time to grow rice with her husband because it is the main source of income for their family.

During the farming season, Lun employed people from her village to transplant rice, but she was unable to pay them as of yet due to a lack of money. Therefore, she is seeking a loan in the amount of US$150 to pay those individuals who transplanted her rice crop. In turn, by using the loan proceeds for payroll purposes, their farming operation will continue to prosper, so they hope that the loan will allow her to generate more income for the family going forward.

loan.use: To pay salaries to villagers who transplanted her rice crop

loan.name: Sarah A.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 33-year-old Sarah A. M. from Tukuyu, married with four children between the ages of 9 and 18. Sarah has been operating a store selling soft drinks and beer since 2006. Assisted by her husband, she works at the business 12 hours per day, 7 days per week, earning about $80 each month.

She is requesting a loan of $250 in order to buy more crates of soft drinks and beer for the business. In the future, she plans to have her own bar. Sarah thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loan.use: To buy more crates of soft drinks and beers.

loan.name: Un

texts.en:
Mrs. Un R. is a breeder in Pour Village in Kampong Cham Province. She raises two cows and two pigs. Since the business is going well, she wants to expand it so she decided to ask for a loan to buy four more pigs for breeding. Her husband, Mr. Phan Bunthoeurn, is a fisherman who can gather a little fish and he also makes a small income to support his family.

Mrs. Un R. is 47 years old and the mother of five children, one of whom is employed in a garment factoR. while another one is a construction worker. Another two are attending the local school, while the youngest one is too young to work or study because that child is at the age of five.

loan.use: To buy four more pigs for breeding.

loan.name: Zikrillo

texts.en:
Zikrillo F. lives in the Abdurahmon Jomi region. He is 49 years old, married and has eleven children. He owns a plot of land where he raises wheat and potatoes and then sells his harvest at the local market. Zikrillo keeps some of the harvest for himself to feed his large family. He has been working as a farmer for the last 10 years. Zikrillo is getting ready for the planting season and wants to take out a loan to purchase seeds and fertilizer. He is planning to pay back the loan in the next 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anya Lyuksyutova, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Purchase of seeds and fertilizer

loan.name: Anna H.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 40-year-old Anna H. M. from Tukuyu. She is married with three children, between the ages of 14 and 18. Anna has been running a stand for selling fish since 1990, selling fish from Mwanza and Kigoma. She works at the business for 12 hours per day, 7 days per week. Anna currently earns about 40 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400 USD in order to buy fish in bulk for reselling. In the future, she plans to open a shop for selling fish by wholesale. Anna thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loan.use: To buy fish in bulk for reselling.

loan.name: Loeub

texts.en:
Mrs. Loeub P., age 48, is a widow who makes and sells traditional Khmer cakes such as Num Ansorm, Num Korm, and Num Bot. The ingredients are sticky rice, sugar, pieces of pork, and peanuts.
All of these kinds of cakes are made by wrapping the sticky rice and peanut mixture in banana leaves and cooking them in a steamy pot. Loeub P. starts cooking her cakes in the early morning. She sells the cakes in different locations in her area, making about $5/day of profit.
Mrs. Loeub P. has five children. Three of them are employed by a factory, one is a goldsmith, and another is enrolled in school.
Mrs. P. needs more capital to expand her business. She has applied for a loan to purchase more ingredients so that she can increase the number of her cakes she makes, as well as her profit margin.

loan.use: To purchase more ingredients to make more cakes

loan.name: Uktam

texts.en: Uktam S. is 61 years old and is married with 4 adult children. His wife helps him in the canteen that he has owned and operated for the past 10 years. Hujamurod cooks his tasty dishes for the people of Penjikent everyday.The canteen is located in the center of the city which allows him access to many customers. With the help of a loan, Uktam would like to expand his business.

loan.use: To expand his business

loan.name: Un

texts.en:
Mrs. Un R. was born in 1960 and lives in Pour Village in the Kampong Cham Province. She owns 1.5 hectare piece of land which she typically uses to grow rice. She is unable to cultivate rice because she does not have enough cows to plow the field. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to purchase another cow to plow the rice field. With the rest of the money she will buy fertilizers and rice seed.

Mrs. Un R. is a 48-year-old widow with two children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory and the other is a construction worker.

loan.use: To purchase a cow and buy fertilizers and rice seed.

loan.name: Chit

texts.en:
Mrs. Chit C., age 31, is married and has two children, ages 6 and 14, who are enrolled in school. She started a business in 2002 selling a variety of vegetables in the market. She earns at least $3.50/day in revenue from her business.
Her husband is motor-taxi driver who transports passengers to different locations in the town, earning around $5/day for his household.
To make her business more profitable, Mrs. Chit C. would like to request a loan from KIVA via CREDIT MFI to expand her inventory. With the rest of the money, she will use to buy a new motorbike for her husband, because his current motorbike is frequently broken and costs her family a lot of money.

loan.use: To buy a new motorbike for her husband

loan.name: Srey

texts.en:
Srey N., age 46, is a widow who lives with six of her ten children in Phnom Penh, Cambodia.
Since 2004, she has had a business making candles to earn a living. She is able to make $10 each day. She is aided by two of her children, one who works in construction and another who is a garment factory worker. Besides making candles, she also works in a recycling business.
Srey N. would like to take out a loan of $1000 to help her candle-making and recycling businesses.

loan.use: To help her candle-making and recycling businesses

loan.name: Avaydillo

texts.en:
Avaydillo N. lives in the Abdurahmon Jomi region. He is 42 years old, married and has five children. He has no formal education and works as a farmer. Avaydillo rents a plot of land where he grows wheat and potatoes. He would like to take out this loan to purchase seeds and fertilizer for the upcoming planting season. Avaydillo is planning to pay back the loan in the next 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anya Lyuksyutova, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Purchase of seeds and fertilizer

loan.name: Asia's Group

texts.en:
Asia has been cooking and selling chapati in Zanzibar since 2002. Chapati is a flat pancake fried in oil and eaten for breakfast or lunch. It can be consumed plain or rolled up with fruits or vegetables inside. Asia works from 8:00am to 9:00pm every day and earns a profit of approximately $35 each month. She is hoping that by taking out her first loan through BRAC Tanzania, she will be able to increase her profit.

Asia is 42 years old, married, and has 4 children, aged 5, 8, 9 and 17. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Mwanahawa, Arata, Kasisa and Asha.

loan.use: To buy more ingredients to cook and sell chapati.

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: To expand her business

loan.name: Abdurazok

texts.en:
Abdurazok S. lives in the Abdurahmon Jomi region. He is 52 years old, married and has eleven children. His family is vast and to support it Abdurazok works in the fields with his older children. He rents land where he grows potatoes and wheat. Abdurazok wants to use this loan for purchasing fertilizer and seeds for the upcoming planting. He plans to pay back the loan in the next 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anya Lyuksyutova, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Purchase of seeds and fertilizer

loan.name: Magdalena U.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 34-year-old Magdalena U. M. from Tukuyu, married with five children between the ages of 9 and 20. Magdalena, who has been running a Vitenge (traditional African womens clothing) shop since 2004, works 10 hours per day, 7 days per week and currently earns about $95 each month from her business.

She is requesting a loan of $250 in order to purchase vitenge in bulk for her business, and in the future plans to have her own clothes shop for catering to a variety of fashions. Magdalena thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loan.use: To purchase vitenge in bulk for reselling.

loan.name: Kung

texts.en:
Mr. Kung M.,33, is a father of two children who are enrolled in primary school. He is a recycler; he buys recyclable items from different locations in his town and resells them to the recycling plants.
With his daily business activity, he can earn at least $3/day for his household. Mr. Kung M. had the idea of starting a recycling business when he saw one of his neighbor start one and realized it could generate a good profit. Since then, he tried the business and has become successful. Moreover, he says, "the more recycling items we buy, the more profit we generate."
He is applying for a loan to purchase more recyclable items from different locations in the town to increase his profit margin.

loan.use: To buy more recyclable items to increase his profit margin.

loan.name: Rehema M.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 34-year-old Rehema M. M. from Tukuyu. Married with two children between the ages of 5 and 11, she is also responsible for supporting two nephews because their parents abandoned them. Rehema has been running a cereal shop since 1999, selling commodities such as maize, beans, groundnuts, and rice. Assisted by her husband, she works at the business 12 hours per day, 6 days per week and earns about $45 monthly.

She is requesting a loan of $250 to purchase cereal crops in bulk for reselling. In the future, she plans to have a milling factory in order to mill maize flour. Rehema thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loan.use: To purchase cereal crops in bulk for reselling.

loan.name: Mirzoyor

texts.en:
Mirzoyor S. lives in the Abdurahmon Jomi region of Tajikistan. He is 49 years old, married and has nine children. Mirzoyor supports his family by farming - he rents land where he grows various grains. Currently he needs to purchase wheat seeds as well as fertilizer for winter planting season and would like to finance the purchase using this loan. Mirzoyor plans to pay back the loan in the next 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anya Lyuksyutova, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Purchase of seeds and fertilizer

loan.name: Prak

texts.en: Prak V., 60, is married and lives with her six children in the Kampong Chhnang province. She earns income growing rice and raising livestock, making about US$3 per day, while her husband (pictured in the photo) works as a land dealer, making US$5 per day. The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year, and inflation has caused food prices to skyrocket. These factors have caused financial difficulties for many Cambodians, Prak V. included. In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of US$1,200 to be able to purchase a motorbike for business.

loan.use: Purchase of a motorbike

loan.name: Bisojida

texts.en: Bisojida T. is 47 years old. For the last 2 years, Bisojida and her husband have been raising cattle. Bisojida raises cattle and then sells them at the market, and at the same time she provides her family with milk products. With the help of the loan, Bisojida plans to increase her livestock and she promises to be accurate in loan repayment.

loan.use: For business expansion

loan.name: Saem

texts.en:
Saem C., 30, is a tailor who operates her business at the local market. In fact, she has a small store where she runs her business. Normally, Saem purchases cloths from suppliers to make clothes to sell, including traditional and modern clothes. She is married to Mr. Chheng An, 27, a motorcycle taxi driver around Kampong Thom Town. Saem has two children, each of whom lives at home and is in school.

To generate additional income, she is seeking a loan to purchase another sewing machine and to buy more cloths to sew and to later sell.

loan.use: To purchase another sewing machine and cloths to sew

loan.name: Rahel F.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 32-year-old Rahel F. Mwasbeja from Tukuyu. Married with two children aged seven and nine,. she is also responsible for supporting two orphans whose parents died of HIV, as well as her brothers children. Rahel has been operating a video business since 2001, working 12 hours per day, 7 days per week, assisted by her husband.

Rahel currently earns about $40 per month from her business and is requesting a loan of $400 in order to buy some screens so that she can start showing videos as well. In the future, she plans to open a theater for showing films. Rahel thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loan.use: To buy some video screens so that she can start showing videos.

loan.name: Govhar

texts.en:
Govhar J. lives in the Abdurahmon Jomi region. She is 40 years old, married and has five wonderful children. Govhar mainly works as a housewife but also grows wheat on a small plot of land on the side. To finance her purchase of seeds and fertilizer she wants to take out this loan which she plans to pay back in the next 10 months.

Translated from Russian by Anya Lyuksyutova, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Purchase of seeds and fertilizer

loan.name: Sem

texts.en: Mrs. Sem S., 33, is married and has a little child. She earns income running her own grocery sales business at her home. Mrs. Sem offers a variety of grocery products and makes an average of US$4 per day. To make her business more profitable, Sem S. has applied for a loan to purchase more products for sale and thus be able to satisfy the growing demand.

loan.use: Purchase of additional grocery products for sale

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: To buy second hand clothes in bulk.

loan.name: Soy

texts.en:
Mrs. Soy N. was born in 1957 and lives in San Daek Village in the Kampong Cham Province. She has two hectares to cultivate rice to earn a living for her family. Her husband, Mr. Uy Nim, is a duck breeder. Since this business is going well, he wants to expand it so his wife decided to ask for a loan to buy more ducks and food to feed them.

The couple has five children, four of whom are employed in a garment factory and one who is attending the local school.

loan.use: To buy more ducks and food for them.

loan.name: Chan

texts.en: Chan P., 33, is married with five children living at home in Kampong Chhnan province. She works grinding rice, typically making US$ 10 each day and her husband is a mechanic and workman. Her husband, Chea Chheung, typically makes about US$ 2 each day. Chan P. would like a loan of US$ 1000 to increase her stocks of rice. She will take off the rice husk and then sell the grains.

loan.use: To grind rice

loan.name: Arzadi

texts.en:
Arzadi A. lives in the Jilikul district. She is involved in a business of fruit sales. She purchases fruit from locals and sells it at the central market. This business brings her just enough income to support her two children. Arzadi is married, however because her husband is unemployed, she has to work more to improve their quality of life. Currently, she plans to obtain a 12-month loan in order to increase goods turnover.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: To increase turnover

loan.name: Yung

texts.en: Mrs. Yung S., 33, is married and lives with her husband and three children, aged 13, 7, and 3, in Bathambong province, Cambodia. To make a living, Yung S. buys garlic from a broker and then re-sells it to people in her community. She earns about US$2 per day in profit, while her husband can make, on average, US$3 per day working as a motor-taxi driver. Yung S. started her business three years ago and has learnt business skills from one of her neighbors. Currently, she has a lot more customers than ever before. To expand her business as well as to increase her profit, Mrs. Yung S. needs more capital to buy a large quantity of garlic to meet the growing customer demands.

loan.use: To buy in a large quantity of garlic to fulfill her client demands.

loan.name: Kan

texts.en:
Mrs. Kan E. is a villager in Trapaing Sla Village in the Kampong Cham Province. She is a farmer and pig breeder. Since the second business is going well, she wants to expand it.Mrs. E. is requesting a loan to buy five more piglets and to buy pig food for her pigs.
Mrs. Kan E. is a 56-year-old widow with a child who is a government officer. Mrs. Kan E. hopes to increase her income after she sells her pigs.

loan.use: To buy five more piglets and pig food.

loan.name: Zuhura W.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 35-year-old Zuhura W. K. from Tukuyu. She is married with two children between the ages of 11 and 14 and is also responsible for supporting two dependents because their parents passed away. Zuhura has been operating a shop since 2005, selling vitenge (see below), bedsheets, sweaters, blankets, and gowns. Assisted by her younger sister, she works 10 hours each day, 7 days per week, currently earning about $85 from her business. She is requesting a loan of $400 in order to buy new clothing to sell, and in the future plans to have a big shop for garments. Zuhura thanks you for your support!

Traditional clothing worn by Tanzanian women is called kanga and vitenge. The kanga is a piece of printed cotton fabric often with a border along all four sides. It is printed using the silkscreen method with its pattern in frames. Kitenge (the Swahili plural is vitenge) is a cotton fabric with wax print, printed by using rotary printing machines. Kitenge is a communicating textile - the various colors, patterns, writings and symbols represent moods, feelings, cultures, and traditions of native African people.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loan.use: To buy more clothing to sell.

loan.name: Gulsara

texts.en: Gulsara has been selling children's clothing for many years. She began her business with less than $100. Gulsara has grown her business substantially and now has her own area in the market where she sells her items everyday. She would like to borrow money to expand her business even more.

loan.use: To purchase more clothing for sale.

loan.name: Chon

texts.en: Chon L., 37, is married and has four children. The family lives in Kampong Chhnang, Cambodia. Although Chon L. is the village chief, he makes less than one dollar per day. On the other hand, his wife, who works as a land dealer, makes around US$10 per day. The couple also raises animals and grows rice to earn extra income. All of their children are students. Chon L. currently needs a loan of US$1,000 to be able to purchase more land to grow rice. He thereby hopes to increase his income and his family's standard of living.

loan.use: Purchase of land to grow rice

loan.name: Rahimjon

texts.en:
Rahimjon L. lives in the city of Kurgan-Tube. He is 22 years old, married and has two children. For the last three years Rahimjon has been managing a shop which he rents from his relatives. He drives in goods from Dushanbe where he can purchase them cheaply from wholesale stores. In order to expand the store's inventory Rahimjon needs to purchase another large batch of goods and he plans to finance the purchase by taking out this loan. He wants to pay back the loan in the next 10 months.

Translated from Russian by Anya Lyuksyutova, Kiva Volunteer

loan.use: Wholesale purchase of goods

loan.name: Fatma's Group

texts.en: Earlier this year, Fatma began making and selling bricks in Zanzibar. She is now seeking her first loan from BRAC Tanzania to help her get her business off the ground. She is married and has three children, ages 5, 4, and one-and-a-half. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Tatu, Fatma, Hasina, Niazao, and Riaiki.

loan.use: To buy more material to make bricks for her business

loan.name: Im

texts.en: Mrs. Im H., 54, has a grocery sales business which she runs from her home. She also helps provide food to the people in her community. Mrs. Im H. started her business in 2004, and by now it has become profitable. As a result of her business activities, she typically makes around US$10 per day. To meet the growing customer demand, however, Mrs. Im H. would like to request a loan of US$700 to be able to expand her grocery inventory by adding more products.

loan.use: Purchase of products for a grocery store

loan.name: Emelia J.

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 55-year-old Emelia J. M. from Tukuyu. She is married with six children between the ages of 18 and 35 and is also responsible for supporting two dependents because they are street children. Emelia, assisted by her husband, has been running a fish-selling business since 2006, working 10 hours per day, 7 days per week.

Currently earning about $35 a month from her business, she is requesting a loan of $250 to increase her bulk purchases of fish in order to realize more profit. In the future, Emelia plans to expand the business. She thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loan.use: To increase her bulk purchases of fish.

loan.name: Oleg

texts.en:
Oleg is married and lives with his wife in Ivano-Frankivsk. He offers transportation services as a taxi driver in his home town. He has been in this business for four years. Oleg's enterprise has benefited a lot from Nadiya Ukraine financial assistance. Presently, he is making about $40-50 of income each day.
Oleg has recently purchased a newer vehicle which runs more smoothly and helps him serve his customers better. Oleg is requesting a 5000 Grivna loan, $975, to pay for his license and insurance. He intends to meet all government requirements and ensure the safety of his clients. Oleg admits that he is very happy to be self-employed. He used to work as a truck driver for a local company, however the taxi business suits him and his lifestyle a lot better. Oleg is hoping to use a portion of his profits to pay for his wife's university fees as she is a student getting a higher education in one of the local universities.

loan.use: pay for license and insurance

loan.name: Ur

texts.en:
Mrs. Ur S. was born in 1965 and lives in Suong Keit Village in the Kampong Cham Province. She owns a small restaurant where she sells food to villagers and tourists. Mrs. Ur S. is a 43-year-old widow with three children, one of whom repairs cars, while the remaining two are attending the local school. The repair business has a problem because of insufficient car parts in inventory.

Mrs. Ur S. decided to ask for a loan to buy car parts for her child who is in the car repair business.

loan.use: To buy car parts for a car repair business.

loan.name: Mak

texts.en: Mak N., 46, is married and lives with her eight children in the Prey Veng province. She and her husband work as vendors selling fruit and typically make about US$5 per day. They are also supported by four of their children who work in a garment factory. Selling fruit has been a difficult business, mostly due to weather conditions that have not been conducive to a good growing season. Therefore, Mak is asking for a loan of US$1,200 to purchase more fruit for sale. She is confident that this loan will help increase her daily income and allow her to better support her family.

loan.use: To purchase more fruits for sale.

loan.name: Chab

texts.en:
Mrs. Chab M., 26, is married with little four children and works as vendor selling fish in her community, making about US$ 5/day in profit. Her husband is a carpenter and in the rainy season he also works as a fisherman, earning $2.50/day.

Chab M. has lately applied for a loan to purchase cows to breed and sell for additional income; the remainder of the loan she will use to expand her business. ( Her husband is pictured because Mrs. Chab M. is not available)

loan.use: To expand her business and buy cows to breed for additional income

loan.name: In

texts.en:
Mrs. In C. is a villager in Suong Keit Village in the Kampong Cham Province. She and her husband, Mr. Sieb Tom, are farmers. They have a problem with their fields because their soil is not fertile. To deal with this problem, Mrs. In C. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers to make the crop more productive.

She is 35-years-old and the mother four children. One child is a fisherman while another paints cars. The second youngest child is attending the local school while the youngest, age five, stays at home. Her husband is on the right in the photo.

loan.use: To buy fertilizers to support the soil and increase crop production.

loan.name: Seng

texts.en: Seng P., 47, is a professional tailor, making US$2.5 per day. She lives in the Kampong Cham province together with one of her five children. Seng is also being supported by one of her sons who works as a mender. Seng P. would like to take out a loan of US$1,000 to set up a hair-dressing shop and a grocery store for her children. The loan would allow Seng and her children to increase their daily income.

loan.use: To set up a hair dressing shop and grocery store for her children.

loan.name: Andrei

texts.en:
Andrei is married to Nadiya and has a 9-year-old son. He lives in Ivano-Frankivsk, Western Ukraine, and offers technical maintenance services at a gas station in his home town. Andrei decided to launch this business because he has always loved working with technical systems. He's been running this business for 6 years. Currently, his daily income is about $100. He has just bought a car for his family to make their life more comfortable.

Andrei is seeking a 3000 Grivna loan that he is hoping to invest in the purchase of vehicle oil. He believes his business policy, that allows deferred payments, will be an attraction for his customers and will help him stand out among his competitors. Andrei has successfully repaid 3 loans to Nadiya Ukraine which has impacted the growth of his business.

Note: this is a short term seasonal loan that will be repaid in 2 months.

loan.use: To purchase 300 liters of motor oil

loan.name: Mong

texts.en:
Mrs. Mong I. was born in 1957 and lives in Trapaning Chork Village in the Kampong Cham Province. She owns 1.5 hectares of land which she uses to cultivate rice to sell. She now faces a small problem because her soil is infertile. To solve this problem, Mrs. Mong I. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers to improve her crop output. Her husband, Mr. Thun Thorn, helps his wife.

Mrs. Mong I. is the mother of three children, two of whom are employed in a coal kiln where they make a small income to help support the family. The remaining one is enrolled in the local school. Her husband is shown on the right of the photo.

loan.use: To buy fertilizers to improve the soil for rice cultivation.

loan.name: Chem

texts.en: Chem M., 34, is married and lives with her husband and their three school-aged children in Kampong Cham, Cambodia. Since 1992, she has been engaged in the business of selling fermented fish and palm sugar to earn a living. On average, Chem M. is able to make about US$2.5 per day. Her husband, working as a taxi-driver, also makes approximately US$2.5 per day. At present, Chem M. would like to take out a loan of US$800 to purchase a motorbike and a trailer to transport the fermented fish and palm sugar.

loan.use: Purchase of a motorbike and a trailer for business

loan.name: Kuy
